I create a [PR](https://github.com/phemisystems/accumulo/pull/1) against this PR.

@rweeks Looking at the code coverage of the unit test I found a few interesting places that were not covered.  Would you like me to annotate these on the PR?  Did not want to do that if you were not interested in seeing it or would rather run CC tool yourself.

> I know you guys require this to be rebased into a single commit. Is that something I can do on my side (I'm concerned about rebasing after I've pushed this to a public repo) or is that something you can do when you receive the pull request?

I am not sure Accumulo has a consensus on this.   Personally, I would rebase the branch into one commit after the the review is complete.
@keith-turner by all means, I'd love to see the code coverage results! Happy to extend the unit tests to cover anything that's missing.

:+1: this looks really good, Russ! Left a couple of comments in the code, but they were mainly stylistic than issues. I would love to also see an integration test that uses this iterator in a "real" environment, but that can be done as a follow-on. Your unit tests exercise this code very well already.

> Christopher switched the fix version to 1.8, I guess because adding new functionality should go into a minor release.

Yeah, this is something we're trying to stick to. Adding this wouldn't be expressly prohibited from older branches because the o.a.a.core.iterators package (and its sub-packages) aren't covered in our public API definition. If you have strong feelings that this should show up in 1.6 or 1.7 too, make your argument (JIRA is probably better than here though).

>  So I'm targeting this against the master branch, because it doesn't look like a 1.8 branch exists yet.

1.8 is the current "latest" so it lives in "master". A 1.8 branch will likely only show up after a 1.8.0 release.
Thanks very much for your feedback, @joshelser  and @keith-turner. If you think it's ready to be merged in, just let me know what I should do on my side to collapse it into one commit.

This is all really great! +1 from me, would be good to hear from @billierinaldi  and/or @ericnewton if they have some time.

The unrelated formatting change will be squashed by me -- I noticed I goofed that up over the weekend.
+1 from me. Will merge today.

This looks great.  Thanks, Dylan!  I have two suggestions.  One is about the sentence, "Span entries record full span information, whereas index and start time entries provide indexing into span information useful for quickly finding spans by type or start time."  Actually both the span and start time entries have the full span information, while only the index entries provide indexing.

The other suggestion is to mention other configuration properties that would need to be set for the zipkin span receiver in accumulo-site.xml and in the client configuration, such as:

```
<property>
  <name>trace.span.receiver.zipkin.collector-hostname</name>
  <value>localhost</value>
</property>
<property>
  <name>trace.span.receiver.zipkin.collector-port</name>
  <value>9410</value>
</property>
```

Thanks for spotting that sentence Billie, will fix tonight.  It's good to
throw in the rest of the Zipkin configuration as well (I was using the
default localhost and port).

On Mon, Aug 24, 2015 at 2:22 PM, billierinaldi notifications@github.com
wrote:

> This looks great. Thanks, Dylan! I have two suggestions. One is about the
> sentence, "Span entries record full span information, whereas index and
> start time entries provide indexing into span information useful for
> quickly finding spans by type or start time." Actually both the span and
> start time entries have the full span information, while only the index

> The other suggestion is to mention other configuration properties that
> would need to be set for the zipkin span receiver in accumulo-site.xml and

> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/accumulo/pull/44#issuecomment-134325576.

Okay, this is set.  On a slightly related note, I see that Zipkin supports HBase, Cassandra and Anorm connections as backing stores for traces.  I wonder how much work it would take to get Zipkin's interface and/or trace-aggregating-statistics to use Accumulo as a backing store.

In 31fcf00 I changed the behaviour slightly.

I dropped the option to throw an exception.  I was thinking this option could prevent problems, but it can not.  It can still only detect problems.  For detecting problems I think logging an error is sufficient.

I also changed logging to log on partial and full major compactions.   If a full major compaction sees a delete, then its evidence that a problem could have occurred in the past with a partial compaction.

The code reads that ACCUMULO_CLIENT_CONF_PATH is meant to be a file (not a directory). Maybe it would be good to also expand these changes to also include expanding it from a directory to $directory/client.conf instead of just ignoring the value?

A unit test would also be super appreciated.
I ended up cherry-picking this in while I was figuring out the broken tests. If you can close this, it'd be great.
There may be value in running some of these test against an iterator stack and not just a single iterator.
For iterators that can be run at major compaction, how can we exercise delete keys?

> For iterators that can be run at major compaction, how can we exercise delete keys?

Very good question! The completely mocked-out IteratorEnvironment is a sign that I haven't thought past the scan case. I'm not even sure if the ColumnFiltering iterator with SortedMapIterator is even a 100% valid in-memory reproduction of how it works in a TabletServer.

I had left input entirely up to the user, so I'm not sure of a simple way to test deletions without potentially messing up some expected table structure. There are some tricky edge cases at compaction that I haven't yet considered how to encapsulate. Combiners on non-full compactions are another good example.
Rat checks in core are passing for me.

Its possible to [set iterators on a Condition](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/1.6.4/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/data/Condition.java#L173) for a [ConditionalMutation](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/1.6.4/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/data/ConditionalMutation.java).  So [ConditionalWriterConfig](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/1.6.4/core/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/core/client/ConditionalWriterConfig.java) should probably have a `setClassLoaderContext(...)` method.
This is a code path that I am not familiar with.

> This is a code path that I am not familiar with.

I can help with that if you like.   I could do it as a follow in issue or a pull req to this pull req.
I think I found it, running the build now.
Can you point me to some tests that I need to modify?

> Can you point me to some tests that I need to modify?

There is [ConditionalWriterIT](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/0e136c1f4276373b09d1a2e4d901c0d16809e6db/test/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/test/ConditionalWriterIT.java).  Maybe could add a test where a conditional mutaton fails w/o a context and succeeds with it.
Also, I added tickets 4054 and 4055 which are related to this.
merged and pushed.
Seems like it would be simpler to modify transaction runner and add a try/catch/log just inside the while loop.

> Seems like it would be simpler to modify transaction runner and add a try/catch/log just inside the while loop.

We very well could do this as well. I was hoping to pick your brain on any worries in just eating those exceptions. I suppose in the end it's no different.

> eating those exceptions

don't just eat them, log them.  

> I suppose in the end it's no different.

Yeah I can't see any differences between the approaches.

Ok, thanks Keith. The only benefit I can see with what I did here is that it supports growing the number of repo runners. That's probably better done as a feature (with shrinking the number of them too), than as a bugfix.

As far as testing goes, I haven't been able to recreate the original situation inside of Accumulo. I have been able to verify that what we were doing does not work. I've done some testing locally found some bugs along the way. I am presently running some CI, and will try to kick off a CI run against some >1 nodes later today.
Just started a full run of the ITs on my jenkins too.

> I have been able to verify that what we were doing does not work.

Can you expand on this?  I am really curious about the behavior of thrift when a oneway throws an exception on the server side.

> Can you expand on this? I am really curious about the behavior of thrift when a oneway throws an exception on the server side.

Best as I understand it: the oneway modifier just equates to the generated code not calling the method to read the response for an RPC off the wire. This has multiple implications:
1. The caller does not know if the application received the message (only that the network connection succeeded).
2. The caller does still receive a response object (this is how void works though, not oneway)
3. If you try to run another RPC that isn't oneway on the same connection, it's possible that the synchronous call will get goofed up by that oneway's void response (this might be a Thrift bug -- it's certainly a pain to work around).

Let me test what actually happens in the client code when the oneway throws an exception. I have a little test harness that I used to play around with this.

> Let me test what actually happens in the client code when the oneway throws an exception. I have a little test harness that I used to play around with this.

So this is funny :). Let's define some stuff:
- Given a request A with response A' over a "normal" synchronous thrift call
- Given a request B with response B' over a oneway thrift call
- Both of these requests are submitted over the same connection
- A is run in one thread, B in another (with a latch to ensure they start at the same time)
1. If A is not submitted and the computation of B' in the server throws an exception, the caller of B does not see this exception. Only side-effect is a server-side log message.
2. If the order of execution as seen by the client is `A, B, B', A'`, the client will typically get an exception trying to read A'
3. If the order of execution as seen by the client is `B, A, A', B'`, then both threads see exceptions.
4. If the order of execution as seen by the client is `B, A, B', A'`, then an exception is seen reading A'

Does this help, @keith-turner?

Interesting.  `#2` should not occur in Accumulo because the connection should be reserved.   `#4` seems like it could occur though.   For `#3` what do you meant when you say `both threads see exceptions`?  Which threads?  I wouldn't think the thread executing the one way would ever see anything, assuming it never waits for a response.  Can you post your test code?
One thing I was curious about in your test code was if you used some synchronization mechanism to force the ordering of something like `B, A, B', A'` vs `B, A, A', B'`.

> #2 should not occur in Accumulo because the connection should be reserved.

Yup, that's right.

>  For #3 what do you meant when you say both threads see exceptions

Per the test setup: two threads are used, one to run A and the other to run B. Another way of saying running both A and B saw exceptions.

The code I was using: https://github.com/joshelser/noway-thrift
wrong branch..

For reference.  The code @joshelser  was talking about  [Thrift 0.9.1 ProcessFunction line 45](https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/0.9.1/lib/java/src/org/apache/thrift/ProcessFunction.java#L45) and [Accumulo 1.7.0 RpcWrapper line 51](https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/1.7.0/server/base/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/server/rpc/RpcWrapper.java#L51)
I think it would be useful to add some comments to the code pointing to ACCUMULO-4065 (and maybe THRIFT-1805 ACCUMULO-2950).  Looking at this code by itself someone would not know why it even exists.

Wonder what happens if a one-way throws a runtime exception and then the connection is put back into the pool.   My expectation is that a closing connection would be put back into the pool, which should be ok.   Whatever tries to use it later would hopefully get a ttransport exception, invalidate the connection, and retry.

> Wonder what happens if a one-way throws a runtime exception and then the connection is put back into the pool

Now? Or with these changes? With these changes, the client will never see an error.

> Now? Or with these changes?

With these changes.

Based on reading @ctubbsii [comment on THRIFT-1805](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-1805?focusedCommentId=14042756&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-14042756), I am assuming that when you rethrow the runtime exception that the server side code will close the connection.   However whatever called the one-way may not be aware of this and would put the connection back into the pool.   I think it will all work out ok, but I was just curious what would happen in practice.
